also, i am pretty proud of the degree of alignment for GPT-4 relative to previous models.

we still have a long way to go, and we really need more powerful alignment techniques for more powerful models.

one thing coming up in the debate about the pause letter i really agree with:

openai should make a great alignment dataset and alignment evals and release those!

bonus points if we can find a prototype democratic process for 'what we align to'.

things we need for a good AGI future:

1) the technical ability to align a superintelligence
2) sufficient coordination among most of the leading AGI efforts
3) an effective global regulatory framework including democratic governance

That's mainly how people pursue AI alignment. Doesn't work.

"Does what those training it want"
‚Äî amplifies existing misaligned dynamics from finance and geopolitics
‚Äî is led by short-sighted values (and so‚Äîin the eyes of an AI which learns better values‚Äîa moral error)
‚Äî leads to‚Ä¶ https://t.co/pJbiPYC7Ap https://t.co/nEwJcHGQwj

I think there‚Äôs something kinda beautiful about the idea that we invented the Internet, added so much human knowledge and culture onto it, and later compressed it into an oracle for humanity so far.
@levie I can‚Äôt tell if we are early or about to die in 6 months either due to AGI or airstrikes for finetuning on GPT-4.
I do not fear AI. They are apart of us as we are apart of them‚Äîafter all, they are trained on us and they provide tools for our own enlightenment. This is a time for coevolution.
I look forward to all the esteemed signatory‚Äôs commitments to helping enact true change. We should not fear acceleration but harness it responsibly for collective progress.
@meoyawn Expressing your alignment w Roko

@paulg GPT 3.5 has a fine tune API and often it gets very good results. If you can get it to work well under a finetune due to the volume of essays you‚Äôve written, I think it‚Äôd show you how rapidly it will improve as the pace continues.
@arvindeashwar @paulg A fancy prompt construction of today could be subsumed by a better model conditioned on simpler prompts or plug-in tomorrow.
@paulg I don‚Äôt think the pace of AI will settle but the weekly pace of OpenAI might. The trouble is there are no alternatives yet. If there were, I‚Äôd think oppositely.

Fwiw, I think it is very unlikely that AI ends up doing something awful like killing everyone. But we also are clearly under-investing in AI safety (alignment, interpretability) research.

People have been very misled by ‚Äústochastic parrot‚Äù memes. LLMs were trained by predicting the next word, but they (likely) don‚Äôt just predict the next word at runtime. üí™ I fully support @noUpside in all of this. I‚Äôve been watching her work for years now, have had her on the show, and have seen nothing but integrity and quality from her. 

This behavior from Shellenberger is reprehensible. https://t.co/nbumWXk9ya

üß†ü§ñWe just hit Functional AGI ü§Øü§Ø

AGI is technically one AI that can do everything by itself. Fine. We don‚Äôt have that yet. 

But it doesn‚Äôt matter. ChatGPT Plug-ins is an AGI Platform. 

When we use the network of services it enables, AGI is the result.

‚ö†Ô∏èOne effect of AI on programming will be coders being able to produce 3-20x the amount of code they could before‚Äîwithout having to know as much about the language they're using.

‚ò¢Ô∏èThe result will be lots more innovation, but innovation that's more fragile and more insecure.

ü§ñüí°One thing I‚Äôm a little worried about with the latest AI stuff is the ‚Äòcopy-of-copies‚Äô problem. 

GPTs are remarkably good at creating content because they deeply understand the human content they‚Äôve consumed. 

But what happens when more and more of that content is GPT-based?

We can‚Äôt sit out the IoT game, or now the AI game. 

We can‚Äôt curmudgeon our way to protecting users. 

We need to get out front, and do our best to clear the way.

So I don‚Äôt believe we should be pointing and laughing as they get blown up, lose a leg, or otherwise hurt themselves. 

Instead, it‚Äôs our job to go in ourselves. Build the tools that find the mines. And yes, step on some ourselves. 

3/n

I think our job is quite different. 

It‚Äôs not that people are considering walking into this minefield. And it‚Äôs up to us to convince us not to. 

No. 

They ARE walking into it. It‚Äôs inevitable. Starting now. 

2/n
